occurrences.line_text: And him reuil'd, and rated, and disdayned,
Her stubborne hart, which loue before disdayned,
As much disdayning to the curbe to yield:
Some of their pride, some paragons disdayning,
But this proude Dame disdayning all accord,
Which I no lesse disdayning, backe returned
That Guyon much disdeignd so loathly sight.
His grated teeth for great disdeigne, and shooke
Disdeigning to be held so long in fight;
As much disdeigning to be so misdempt,
Till Diamond disdeigning long delay
Disdeining life, desiring leaue to die,
The griefe thereof him wondrous sore diseasd,
Said Guyon, Squire, sore haue ye beene diseasd;
A vile disease, and eke in foote and hand
In that disease of grieued conscience,
His double burden did him sore disease.
Of the rough rockes, do diuersly disease,
And fell to vaine voluptuous disease:
But labour'd long in that deepe ford with vaine disease.
Dissembling his disease and euill plight;
Nought could she read the roote of his disease,
Through his disease, did by and by out find,
Lying without her dore in great disease;
The bitter anguish of their sharpe disease,
So all that night they past in great disease,
Which tosse the rest in daungerous disease?
For pitty of his Dame, whom she saw so diseased.
Full of diseases was his carcas blew,
As if he thought her soule to disentrayle.
He broke, and did his bowels disentrayle;
And all the while the disentrayled blood
Her swollen eyes were much disfigured,
She gins her feathers foule disfigured
To wish you backe returne with foule disgrace,
For to all knighthood it is foule disgrace,
And with foule vgly forme did her disgrace:
To many knights did daily worke disgrace;
With balefull beggerie, or foule disgrace,
And fly away for feare of fowle disgrace:
The goddesse wroth gan fowly her disgrace,
For feare through want of skill her beautie to disgrace?
The knight yet wrothfull for his late disgrace,
Whereof conceiuing shame and foule disgrace,
Or else for feare of shame and fowle disgrace.
In vengement of her mothers great disgrace,
Ah wofull man, what heauens hard disgrace,
When they are all restor'd, thou shalt rest in disgrace.
She inly yet conceiued great disgrace.
With bitter taunts, and termes of vile disgrace.
Did her appeach, and to her more disgrace,
Sayd Artegall; What foule disgrace is this,
Into this bay of perill and disgrace?
I leaue to you, for aye me to disgrace
Faire Lady let it not you seeme disgrace,
Were vanquished, and put to foule disgrace,
And her good dayes in dolorous disgrace:
That though the night did couer her disgrace,
And in the sight of all men cleane disgraced,
Being all rag'd and tatter'd, their disgraces
Disgracing them, him selfe thereby to grace,
Disarmd, disgrast, and inwardly dismayde,
But it would lose or breake, that many had disgrast.
So had false Archimago her disguisd,
He then deuisde himselfe how to disguise;
And diuerse plots did frame, to maske in strange disguise.
Discolour'd like to womanish disguise,
Some, that it was a maske of strange disguise:
Thus as they marched all in close disguise,
In quyent disguise, full hard to be descride.
Magnificke Virgin, that in queint disguise
But thinking best by counterfet disguise
Disguised like that groome of base degree,
Disguised slaine, ere any thereof thought:
Made her dissemble her disguised kind:
His garment was disguised very vaine,
Forthwith themselues disguising both in straunge
But are into these fearefull shapes disguiz'd
Disguiz'd in thousand shapes, that none might him bewray.)
Whom when she saw in wretched weedes disguiz'd,
Of our like persons eath to be disguiz'd,
Of men disguiz'd in womanishe attire,
Let vs in feigned armes our selues disguize,
Least he like one of them him selfe disguize,
In straunge disguize, to slake his scalding smart;
Most answerable to his wyld disguize
Whom like disguize no lesse deformed had,
How she the blame might salue with coloured disguize.
But suffred her so carelesly disguized
All which disguized marcht in masking wise,
And mazd how nature had so well disguized
How coul[d]st thou weene, through that disguized hood,
That in so straunge disguizement there did maske,
She through his late disguizeme[n]t could him not descrie.
In a discolour'd cote, of straunge disguyse,
And him dishabled quite. But he was wise
But her old Nourse was nought dishartened,
What needs of daintie dishes to deuize,
For day discouers all dishonest wayes,
And her accusing of dishonesty,
And shund dishonor, which as death she feard:
To blot her with dishonor of so faire a pray.
Yet dread of shame, and doubt of fowle dishonor
And all true louers with dishonor blotten,
And forst him backe with fowle dishonor to retreat.
The which shal nought to you but foule dishonor yearne.
Of these poore folk, whose soules with black dishonor
Then with dishonorable termes her to entreat.
He found himselfe dishonored so sore.
There lies he now with foule dishonour dead,
That noble heart as great dishonour doth despize.
Late foule dishonour and reprochfull spight,
Shame and dishonour hath vnto me donne;
Saying, Sir knight, it would dishonour bee
And armes dishonour with base villanie,
Dye rather, then doe ought, that mote dishonour yield.
Besides the great dishonour and defame,
With foule dishonour him mote blot therefore;
What cause could make him so dishonourable,
To be by them dishonoured and shent:
To thinke how this long death thou mightest disinherit.
Disleall knight, whose coward courage chose
Ne do your selfe dislike a whit the more;
Without disquiet or dislike of ether,
Or selfe disliked life doth thee thus wretched make?
Dislikefull paine, so sad a taske to take,
And of all old dislikes they made faire weather,
And loue for to dislodge out of his nest:
Or them dislodge, all were they liefe or loth;
Would streight dislodge the wretched wearie life.
Vnto my Lambes, and him dislodge away;
Where finding life not yet dislodged quight,
Low looking dales, disloignd from common gaze;
Disloyall Treason, and hart-burning Hate,
Such was the end, that to disloyall loue did fall.
Discourteous, disloyall Britomart,
And made him dreame those two disloyall were:
Dye rather, dye, then so disloyally
Dye rather, dy, then euer loue disloyally.
Inconstant Chaunge, and false Disloyaltie,
But if to loue disloyalty it bee,
That to disloyalty she will not be allured.
Ne euer shewed signe of foule disloyalty.
When two so mighty warriours he dismade:
Her faithfull gard remou'd, her hope dismaid,
That purest skye with brightnesse they dismaid:
Thereto said he, Faire Dame be nought dismaid
Who him disarmed, dissolute, dismaid,
The sight whereof so throughly him dismaid,
The deadly dint his dulled senses all dismaid.
Came running in, much like a man dismaid,
Great pittie is to see you thus dismaid,
Of her sweet words, that all his sence dismaid,
But you, faire Sir, be not herewith dismaid,
Gentle Madame, why beene ye thus dismaid,
That nigh he breathlesse grew, yet nought dismaid,
And looking round about, like one dismaid,
Which sodaine accident him much dismaid,
The groning ghosts of many one dismaide
The Gyant selfe dismaied with that sownd,
Dismaied with so desperate deadly wound,
Yet all that did not her dismaied make,
That horse and man he equally dismaies,
Dismayd with that deformed dismall sight,
What dismall day hath lent this cursed light,
An vgly feend, more fowle then dismall day,
And said, Paynim, this is thy dismall day;
This dismall day hath thee a caytiue made,
Now freed from feare and danger of that dismall wight.
That euer I this dismall day did see:
Or else what other deadly dismall day
The morrow next, that was the dismall day,
He much was daunted with so dismall sight;
For such a dismall deed, their guilt to hyde:
This dismall day, and was not dead before,
Threatning her angry sting, him to dismay:
For present cause was none of dread her to dismay.
But suddaine catching hold, did her dismay
And her darke griesly looke them much dismay;
But when as monsters huge he would dismay,
The chearelesse man, whom sorrow did dismay,
Ne diuelish thoughts dismay thy constant spright.
Sometimes great hostes of men she could dismay,
When sin, and hell, and death do most dismay
And rolling downe, great Neptune doth dismay;
The sight with idle feare did them dismay,
The hartlesse Hind and Robucke to dismay,
Dismay with feare, or cause one foot to flie,
But did him deadly daunt, or fowle dismay;
Should him dismay, and make him stoup so low,
On him, that did Pyrrochles deare dismay:
Ne darkenesse him, ne daunger might dismay.
And vgly shapes did nigh the man dismay,
Whiles deadly fit thy pupill doth dismay;
And more had wasted, could no whit dismay;
Yet would he not for all his great dismay
With constancy and care, gainst daunger and dismay.
Huge hostes of men he could alone dismay,
Hast learn'd to loue, let no whit thee dismay
A virgin strange and stout him should dismay, or kill.
That Proteus prophecide should him dismay,
And fain'd to cheare his Ladie in dismay;
Him bet so sore, that life and sense did much dismay.
With vpstart haire, and staring eyes dismay,
Ne canst her ayde, ne canst her foe dismay:
Yet fairely well he did them all dismay:
And their possessours often did dismay.
Ah Sir (said Paridel) do not dismay
Ne word he had to speake for great dismay,
Which had so great dismay so well amended,
The sight of whom once seene did all the rest dismay.
That her great daunger did him much dismay.
Those Ladies two yet doubtfull through dismay
As on the ground, without dismay or dread:
Vpon a rocke with horrible dismay,
Yet nought they could him hurt, ne ought dismay.
So sharpe a battell, that so many did dismay.
Partly with shame, and partly with dismay,
Seem'd to awake in horrible dismay,
So did the sight thereof their sense dismay,
whom Talus doth dismay,
There he her found in sorrow and dismay,
Your owne good shield in daungerous dismay?
She forth was brought in sorrowfull dismay,
Began to quake and tremble with dismay;
With hearts dismay and inward dolour queld,
Where of the Lady selfe in sad dismay
Then forth he cald from sorrowfull dismay
To succour her, from daunger of dismay;
In dolorous dismay and deadly plight,
Serena full of dolorous dismay,
Nor his fierce steed, that mote him much dismay,
With the fierce Lapithes, which did them dismay;
Where Pastorell? who full of fresh dismay,
All cleane dismayd to see so vncouth sight,
Why Dame (quoth he) what hath ye thus dismayd?
And all his senses were with suddeine dread dismayd.
Vpstaring stiffe, dismayd with vncouth dread;
To weet, what mister wight was so dismayd:
Dismayd with that deformed dismall sight,
Whom so dismayd when that his foe beheld,
He woxe dismayd, and gan his fate to feare;
My Lord, my King, be nought hereat dismayd,
Welling out streames of teares, and quite dismayd
Deadly dismayd, with horrour of that dint
And maistring might on enimy dismayd:
And though him selfe were at the sight dismayd,
Ran to his hart, and all his sence dismayd,
His cruell bow, wherewith he thousands hath dismayd.
Some like to hounds, some like to Apes, dismayd,
Of huge Sea monsters, such as liuing sence dismayd.
Thereat they greatly were dismayd, ne wist
The fourth was by that other knight dismayd,
But with her dreadfull strokes were all dismayd:
Daughter (said she) what need ye be dismayd,
Then shall the Britons, late dismayd and weake,
Or other ghastly spectacle dismayd,
His vncouth shield and straunge armes her dismayd,
Couered with cloudes, her Pilot hath dismayd;
The whiles her matchlesse beautie him dismayd.
Her Amoretta cald, to comfort her dismayd.
Which whenas she perceiu'd, she was dismayd
To counsell her so carefully dismayd,
He was dismayd, and thrise his breast he stroke,
Gan greatly chaunge, and seem'd dismayd to bee;
In his disquiet mind was much dismayd:
Greatly thereat was Britomart dismayd,
That euery wight dismayd with darknesse sad,
That sight of such a chaunge her much dismayd.
And shame, he shewd him selfe to be dismayd,
And foule aduantage this good Knight dismayd,
Whom so dismayd when Cambell had espide,
As one that seemed doubtfull or dismayd.
He with their multitude was nought dismayd,
Dismayd, that none of them in field durst stand,
And ghesse the man to be dismayd with gealous dread.
Yet she no whit dismayd, her steed forsooke,
He was therewith right wondrously dismayd,
Till Glauce thus; Faire Sir, be nought dismayd
And all dismayd through mercilesse despaire,
Yet nought dismayd, them stoutly well withstood;
The trembling foule dismayd with dreadfull sight
He was therewith exceedingly dismayd;
Dismayd so with the stroke, that he no colours knew.
Besides the rest dismayd, might not be nombred:
That many hath with dread of death dismayd,
With sight whereof she was dismayd right sore,
And doubtfully dismayd through that so vncouth sight.
Or ill apayd, or much dismayd ye be,
She was dismayd, or faynted through affright,
So vgly creature, she was nigh dismayd,
And much dismayd with that dismayfull sight,
Her halfe dismayd they found in doubtfull plight,
Whereat the other starting vp dismayd,
But the bold knight no whit thereat dismayd,
Whom when as Calepine saw so dismayd,
And leauing there this Ladie all dismayd,
Whom when the Prince so deadly saw dismayd,
And saw him selfe captiu'd, he was dismayd,
Vnto her mistresse, being halfe dismayd,
His mortall mace, wherewith his foemen he dismayde.
Disarmd, disgrast, and inwardly dismayde,
That with so troublous terrour they were all dismayde.
She could it sternely draw, that all the world dismayde.
Hastily starting vp, like men dismayde,
He was dismayed in his coward mind,
Was much dismayed with that dreadfull sight:
As a dismayed Deare in chace embost,
By her I entring halfe dismayed was,
Ne ought dismayed was Sir Calidore,
So much the dart of sinfull guilt the soule dismayes.
And much dismayd with that dismayfull sight,
From which like mazed deare, dismayfully they flew.
Their mightie strokes their haberieons dismayld,
And quite dismembred hath: the thirstie land
Was quite dismembred, and his members chast
Yet, had the bodie not dismembred bee,
Eftsoones dismounted from his courser braue,
So him dismounted low, he did compell
But soone as him dismounted on the plaine,
Let not thee grieue dismounted to haue beene,
But all of them likewise dismounted were,
Dismounting lightly from his loftie steed,
Which when that warriour heard, dismounting straict
And from his loftie steed dismounting low,
There they dismounting, drew their weapons bold
But from my lofty steede dismounting low,
And low dismounting from his loftie steede,
But Burbon streight dismounting from his steed,
Where soft dismounting like a weary lode,
Dismounting light, his shield about him threw,
Yet durst he not his mother disobay,
Faire Sir, be not displeasd, if disobayd:
Not one was left, that durst her once haue disobayd.
And droue away their flocks, with other much disorder.
Clad in faire weedes, but fowle disordered,
So all confounded and disordered there.
She her gay painted plumes disorderid,
One might haue seene enraung'd disorderly,
Disordred hong about his shoulders round,
To be disordred by some accident:
He drenched was, she at the length dispacht him,
His chamber was dispainted all within,
This squalid weede, the patterne of dispaire,
Reuiued was, and sad dispaire away did cast.
Dissuaded her from such a disparage.
How shall fraile pen, with feare disparaged,
And thought that match a fowle disparagement:
But for his meannesse and disparagement,
The gentle heart scornes base disparagement.
And great disparagment makes to his former might.
Them in twelue troupes their Captain did dispart
Themselues they did dispart, each to assay,
And the wyde wound, which lately did dispart
And doe dispart the hart with powre extreme,
Both linckt together neuer to dispart,
Vnto the Knight, them to dispart in twaine:
On either side disparted with his rod,
That quite disparted all the linked frame,
Doubly disparted, it did locke and close,
Perforce disparted their compacted gyre,
So they disparted were, and all men went to rest.
That they disparted them, maugre their might,
That the disdainfull soule he thence dispatcht,
For many yeares of sorrow can dispence:
It was a vaut ybuilt for great dispence,
Was poured forth with plentifull dispence,
When so it needs with rigour to dispence.
Dealing his dreadfull blowes with large dispence,
And such fond fauours sparingly dispenst:
That all his manly powres it did disperse,
Vpblowing, doth disperse the vapour lo'st,
So did that Squire his foes disperse, and driue asonder.
Infinite shapes of things dispersed thin;
To seeke their loues dispersed diuersly,
Dispersed all their troupe incontinent,
But like a sort of sheepe dispersed farre
Disperseth them to catch his choysest pray;
The force, which wont in two to be disperst,
Disperst the shadowes of the mistie night,
Thus when they had that troublous rout disperst,
And with his sword disperst the raskall flockes,
Loosely disperst with puffe of euery blast:
Was all disperst out of the firmament,
Spurring so hote with rage dispiteous,
In your auengement and dispiteous rage,
Whom leauing there in that dispiteous plight,
With so fell fury, and dispiteous forse,
Through her dispiteous pride, whilest loue lackt place,
From thence he threw himselfe dispiteously,
He saw his life powrd forth dispiteously:
For th'heauens haue decreed, to displace
Perceth the yielding ayre, and doth displace
And plast on his, he did it soone displace,
That my ill fortune did them hence displace.
About her cursed head, whose folds displaid
And golden foile all ouer them displaid,
But griefe (quoth she) does greater grow displaid,
And ornaments that richly were displaid;
Her selfe so deckt, her nimble wings displaid,
Halfe like a serpent horribly displaide,
Faire feeling words he wisely gan display,
And hide the smoke, that did his fire display,
His flaggy wings when forth he did display,
The Northerne wind his wings did broad display
And then by it his wearie limbes display,
Did neuer in that house it selfe display,
His glory did enhaunce, and pompous pride display.
So hauing said, eftsoones he gan display
And did themselues through all the North display:
During which time her powre she did display
Her bared bosome she doth broad display;
In which they creeping did at last display
For liuing wit, I weene, cannot display
And then his spirite thus gan forth display;
By which the Redcrosse knight did earst display
When Titan faire his beames did display,
Vpbounden, did them selues adowne display,
And very Florimell, did her display:
And all the engins of her wit display;
The plot of all her practise did display,
Thereto addresse, and his bright shield display.
To loose the badge, that should his deedes display.
So soone as it did to the world display
That him did much renowme, and far his fame display.
Another while I baytes and nets display,
Be farre fro me, to whom ye ill display
Through the bright heauen doth her beams display,
Now whenas darkesome night had all displayd
And pillow was my helmet faire displayd:
Close vnder his left wing, then broad displayd.
There he him found all carelesly displayd,
That heauenly grace so plenteously displayd;
And her two lilly paps aloft displayd,
And the old-woman carefully displayd
Vpon her fell all naked bare displayd;
This crafty Paramoure, and now it plaine displayd.
Chamber are displayd,
With scutchins gilt and banners broad displayd:
And let that losell, plainely now displayd,
Loosely displayd vpon the grassie ground,
Tho when as all her plaints she had displayd,
That when thy glory shall be farre displayd
With cloud of death vpon her eyes displayd;
In which that rose she plainely saw displayd.
Then with his wauing wings displayed wyde,
The God of loue, with wings displayed wide,
Hath in a watry cloud displayed wide
That fame in trompe of gold eternally displayes.
The prayses of high God he faire displayes,
At length breakes forth, and brode displayes his smyling hew.
Euen so the baser mind it selfe displayes,
Was wont him once to disple euery day:
To paint it forth, him to displeasance moou'd,
Without displeasance for to proue his spere.
Faire Sir (quoth she) be not displeasd at all;
Mammon was much displeasd, yet no'te he chuse,
Faire Sir, be not displeasd, if disobayd:
Thereat displeasd they were, till that young Squire
Sorely thereat he was displeasd, and thought
But her therewith full sore displeasd he found,
That stroke the hardy Squire did sore displease,
And pardon simple man, that rash did him displease.
She would her selfe displease, so him requite.
But should it not displease thee it to tell;
Which lately sought his Lord for to displease:
Thereat the curteous knight displeased was,
(Said he) that thee so sore displeased hath?
Whom when as Venus saw so sore displeased,
Beheld, he woxe therewith displeased sore,
She inly were, and in her mind displeased.
Both Amidas and Philtra were displeased:
With which rude speach his Lady much displeased,
Or ought haue done, that ye displeasen might,
And gnasht his yron tuskes at that displeasing sight.
Of high displeasure, that ensewen might,
Whom Princes late displeasure left in bands,
Who nought regarding her displeasure forward goth.
Who for some light displeasure, which him crost,
After them went Displeasure and Pleasance,
In great displeasure, that he could not get her.
That the displeasure of the mighty is
Her gentle Squire through her displeasure did pertake.
As when Dan AEolus in great displeasure,
For that displeasure; and thinke what reliefe
He soone allayd that Knights conceiu'd displeasure,
And the strong course of their displeasure breake,
In great displeasure, wild a Capias
Of that displeasure, broke his bag-pipe quight,
But then the Captaine fraught with more displeasure,
And bring into a mighty Peres displeasure,
For dread of her displeasures vtmost proofe.
And all forepast displeasures to repeale.
Your high displesure, through misdeeming bred:
With faire disport and courting dalliaunce
Full of disport, still laughing, loosely light,
They sdeigned such lasciuious disport,
Her to disport, and idle time to pas,
She list not heare, but her disports poursewd,
Their fit disports with faire delight doe chose,
